Enhanced reasoning process using retrieved knowledge:
F. Scott Fitzgerald was an American novelist and short story writer, best known for his novel "The Great Gatsby" and for being a prominent figure in the "Jazz Age" of the 1920s. He was born in St. Paul, Minnesota in 1896 and attended Princeton University. Fitzgerald's literary career flourished during the 1920s, and he became a key figure in the cultural movement known as the "Jazz Age." His writing often reflected the social and moral issues of the time, and his works continue to be studied and celebrated for their portrayal of American society in the early 20th century.

Fitzgerald's personal life was marked by struggles with alcoholism and mental health issues, as well as his tumultuous relationship with his wife, Zelda Sayre. These personal challenges often influenced his writing and added depth to his characters and themes.

Answer:
F. Scott Fitzgerald was an American novelist and short story writer, best known for his novel "The Great Gatsby" and for being a prominent figure in the "Jazz Age" of the 1920s. He was a key figure in American literature, known for his exploration of the social and moral issues of his time through his writing.
